body:
```
$ cat /etc/*-release | grep \^NAME; python --version; cython --version    
NAME="Arch Linux"
Python 3.5.2
Cython version 0.24.1
```

Let's create a dummy pyx in a subfolder and cythonize it:
```
$ mkdir srcdir && touch srcdir/empty.pyx && cythonize -b srcdir/empty.pyx
Compiling /tmp/foo/srcdir/empty.pyx because it changed.
[1/1] Cythonizing /tmp/foo/srcdir/empty.pyx
<elided>
```
The `.c` ends up next to the source, but the `.so` ends up somewhat unhelpfully in the current folder:
```
$ ls -R
.:
build  srcdir  empty.cpython-35m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so

./build:
temp.linux-x86_64-3.5

./build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.5:
tmp

./build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.5/tmp:
foo

./build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.5/tmp/foo:
srcdir

./build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.5/tmp/foo/srcdir:
empty.o

./srcdir:
empty.c  empty.pyx
```
title: cythonize -b puts the built module in the current directory rather than next to the source
